fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a representable morphism in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}. Given {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{\gamma }}{\Gamma } and \Delta \vdash a : A\gamma , we shall write {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}}}{\Gamma .A} for the universal map below:

Given {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{\gamma }}{\Gamma }, \Delta \vdash B, \Gamma \vdash A, and \Delta .B\vdash a : A\gamma p_B, we shall write {\Delta .B}\xrightarrow {{\gamma .a}}{\Gamma .A} for the universal map {\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma \circ p_B,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}.

Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a morphism in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}, and let \Gamma be a representable object. We shall use the following notations inspired by dependent type theory to refer to elements of U and E:

html:ol.html:li: We shall write {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash _p A\right )\mathclose {}} to refer to a morphism {\Gamma }\xrightarrow {{A}}{U}.

Given {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash _p A\right )\mathclose {}}, we shall write {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash _p a : A\right )\mathclose {}} to refer to a morphism {\Gamma }\xrightarrow {{a}}{E} such that the composite \Gamma \xrightarrow {a}E\xrightarrow {p}U is equal to {\Gamma }\xrightarrow {{A}}{U}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A morphism {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} in \operatorname {Pr}{\mathcal {C}} is called representable when for every \Gamma \vdash _p A, the fiber product \Gamma .A :\equiv E\times _U\Gamma is representable:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <sq/>{ nw = \Gamma .A, sw = \Gamma , ne = E, se = U, east = p, south = A, west = p_A, north = q_A, nw/style = pullback, } \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a representable morphism in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}. Given {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{\gamma }}{\Gamma } and \Delta \vdash a : A\gamma , we shall write {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}}}{\Gamma .A} for the universal map below:

Given {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{\gamma }}{\Gamma }, \Delta \vdash B, \Gamma \vdash A, and \Delta .B\vdash a : A\gamma p_B, we shall write {\Delta .B}\xrightarrow {{\gamma .a}}{\Gamma .A} for the universal map {\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma \circ p_B,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}.

fr:title.text: The adjunction determined by a representable map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The adjunction determined by a representable map

fr:title.text: The generic elements functor of a representable map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The generic elements functor of a representable map

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a representable map in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}. We shall define the generic elements functor {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{q}}{\widetilde {E}} that, intuitively, sends an element of the base to the generic element of the fiber of {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} at that element.

html:li.html:p: Fixing an element \Gamma \vdash A, we define qA to be the upstairs map in the following pullback square that exists by representability of {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U}, and can be chosen by the univalence principle for the category \mathcal {C}:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw/style = pullback, nw = \Gamma .A, sw = \Gamma , se = U, ne = E, south = A, north = qA, east = p, west = p_A, north/style = {thick,->}, }

html:li.html:p: Fixing a morphism {A}\xrightarrow {{\bar \gamma }}{B} in \widetilde {U} over {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{\gamma }}{\Gamma } in \mathcal {C}, we choose {qA}\xrightarrow {{q\bar \gamma }}{qB} to be the upper triangle determined by the universal property of the pullback as follows:

Commutation of the outer square follows from the homomorphism property of {A}\xrightarrow {{\bar \gamma }}{B} in \widetilde {U}. The assignment preserves identities and compositions, so we have defined a functor {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{q}}{\widetilde {E}}.

fr:title.text: The weakening counit of a representable map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The weakening counit of a representable map

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a representable map in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}, so that {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{q}}{\widetilde {E}} is the corresponding generic elements functor. We may define a natural transformation {\widetilde {p}\circ q}\xrightarrow {{\epsilon }}{1_{\widetilde {U}}} that we shall call the weakening counit of the representable map {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U}.
For \Gamma \vdash A we define the component {\widetilde {p}qA}\xrightarrow {{\epsilon _A}}{A} to be the following cell over {\Gamma .A}\xrightarrow {{p_A}}{A}:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <sq/>{ nw = \Gamma .A, sw = \Gamma , west/style = {exists,->}, se = U, ne = E, east = p, south = A, west = p_A, north = q A, } \node [between = sq/nw and sq/se] {${\Downarrow }\epsilon _A$}; \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The reason to name \epsilon _A as we have done is that it witnesses the fact that weakening a given type \Gamma \vdash A into the context of its generic element gives you precisely the type of the generic element.

fr:title.text: The substitution unit of a representable map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The substitution unit of a representable map

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a representable map in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}, so that {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{q}}{\widetilde {E}} is the corresponding generic elements functor. We may define a natural transformation {1_{\widetilde {E}}}\xrightarrow {{\eta }}{q\circ \widetilde {p}} that we shall call the substitution unit of the representable map {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U}.
We define {1_{\widetilde {E}}}\xrightarrow {{\eta }}{q\circ \widetilde {p}} assigning to each \Gamma \vdash a : A the upper-hand depicted below:

The reason to refer to {1_{\widetilde {E}}}\xrightarrow {{\eta }}{q\circ \widetilde {p}} as the substitution unit is that it witnesses the fact that every element of a given type arises from that types generic element by substitution.

fr:title.text: Snake identity: duplicating the generic element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Snake identity: duplicating the generic element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The following snake identity for the substitution unit and the weakening counit holds for any representable map {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}:
As we shall see in the proof below, this identity states that duplicating the generic element gives you the generic element (up to weakening).
We first instantiate the snake diagram at an arbitrary {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash A\right )\mathclose {}}\in \widetilde {U}.

As {\widetilde {E}}\xrightarrow {{\pi _E}}{\mathcal {C}} is a discrete fibration, it suffices to check that the above diagram lies over an identity cell in \mathcal {C}. We therefore consider its image in \mathcal {C} as an endomorphism on \Gamma .A to check that it is the identity, computing as follows using the componentwise definitions of the substitution unit and the weakening counit:

These two maps evidently compose to the identity: indeed, by the universal property of \Gamma .A as the fiber product E\times _U\Gamma , it suffices to check that qA\circ p_A.qpqA\circ {\mathopen {}\left \langle \Gamma .A,qA\right \rangle \mathclose {}} = qA and p_A\circ p_A.qpqA\circ {\mathopen {}\left \langle \Gamma .A,qA\right \rangle \mathclose {}} = p_A, as can be read off from the diagrams below.
The following snake identity for the substitution unit and the weakening counit holds for any representable map {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}:
As we shall see, this law states that any element \Gamma \vdash a : A gives rise to a section of the display map {\Gamma .A}\xrightarrow {{p_A}}{\Gamma }.

We may instantiate the snake diagram at an arbitrary {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash a:A\right )\mathclose {}}\in \widetilde {E}, and we may whisker on the right with {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{\pi _U}}{\mathcal {C}} which, as a discrete fibration, is a faithful functor. It suffices now to check that the resulting cell is an identity map \mathcal {C}. We we compute it below using the componentwise definitions of the substitution unit and weakening counit.

The cell depicted above is indeed an identity, as {\Gamma }\xrightarrow {{\Gamma .a}}{\Gamma .A} is defined to be the section of {\Gamma .A}\xrightarrow {{p_A}}{\Gamma } determined by {\Gamma }\xrightarrow {{a}}{E}.

fr:title.text: Adjointness of the generic elements functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjointness of the generic elements functor

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a representable map in \operatorname {Pr}{\mathcal {C}}; then we have an adjunction \widetilde {p}\dashv q where {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{q}}{\widetilde {E}} is the generic elements functor of {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U}, in which the unit and counit are the substitution unit and weakening counit respectively.
We have verified the two snake identities in Lemmas [jms-00DP] and [jms-00DQ] respectively.

Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a morphism in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C}; if the induced functor {\widetilde {E}}\xrightarrow {{\widetilde {p}}}{\widetilde {U}} between categories of elements has a right adjoint, then {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} is representable.

Let there be a right adjoint {\widetilde {U}}\xrightarrow {{q}}{\widetilde {E}} to {\widetilde {E}}\xrightarrow {{\widetilde {p}}}{\widetilde {U}}, and fix {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash A\right )\mathclose {}}\in \widetilde {U}. Applying the right adjoint, we have an element {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma .A\vdash qA\right )\mathclose {}}\in \widetilde {E}; instantiating the counit at {\mathopen {}\left (\Gamma \vdash A\right )\mathclose {}}, we have a cell {\widetilde {p}qA}\xrightarrow {{\epsilon _{A}}}{A}, which amounts to a commuting square in the following configuration:

It suffices to show that the square depicted above is cartesian. Because pullbacks in presheaf categories are computed pointwise, it suffices to consider only squares with a representable apex, such as the one below in which \Delta is assumed representable:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = \Delta , sw = \Gamma , ne = E, se = U, west = \gamma , east = p, north = a, south = A, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To construct the universal map {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}}}{\Gamma .A} factoring \gamma ,a through qA,p_A respectively, we note the square above corresponds precisely to a morphism {\widetilde {p}a}\xrightarrow {{\bar \gamma }}{A} in \widetilde {U}, visualised as follows:
We can transpose {\widetilde {p}a}\xrightarrow {{\gamma }}{A} to obtain the following {a}\xrightarrow {{\bar \gamma ^\sharp }}{qA} in \widetilde {E}:

We now define {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}}}{\Gamma .A} to be the image of {a}\xrightarrow {{\bar \gamma ^\sharp }}{qA} in \mathcal {C}, i.e. {\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}} :\equiv \pi _E \bar \gamma ^\sharp .The factorisation qA\circ {\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}} = a holds by inspection of the above diagram in \widetilde {E}. The other factorisation p_A \circ {\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}} = \gamma holds by the snake identities of adjoints:

Uniqueness of {a}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}}}{qA} with this property can be seen as follows. We fix any {\Delta }\xrightarrow {{h}}{\Gamma .A} satisfying the two factorisation properties; in other words, we assume that h lies underneath a morphism in {a}\xrightarrow {{\bar {h}}}{qA} in \widetilde {E} satisfying (only) the additional property that \epsilon _A\circ \bar {h} = \gamma :
To see that h = {\mathopen {}\left \langle \gamma ,a\right \rangle \mathclose {}}, it therefore suffices to observe the following instance of the snake identity:

A morphism {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} is representable in \operatorname {Pr}\mathcal {C} if and only if the induced functor {\widetilde {E}}\xrightarrow {{\widetilde {p}}}{\widetilde {U}} has a right adjoint.
